The \pkg{exPrior} packages provides real-world geostatistical data from the World-Wide HYdrological Parameters DAtabank wwwhypda as well as methods for accessing these data using R with the functions \texttt{viewInfo()} and \texttt{getData()}. In this vignette, we are going to exemplify the use of exPrior using these data.

First, we should load the libraries to get access to this function:

```{r}
library(exPrior)
library(ggplot2)
library(gtable)
library(grid)
library(gstat)
```

Let us start by importing data on porosity in sandstone aquifers from the data base.
 
```{r}
exdata <- getData(rockType ='Sandstone', param ='porosity')
```
  
These real-world, ex-situ data can now be used to compute the ex-situ prior using the `exPrior` function (see the vignette simple_example).

```{r}
resExPrior = genExPrior(exdata = exdata, theta = seq(from=0, to=1, by=0.01))
```

Here, the range of the `theta` vector reflects the common-sense intuition that porosity values can only be found between `0` and `1`.

Aftern the completion of `exPrior`, we can visualize both the uninformative and informative distribution of $\theta$ using `plotExPrior`. This function again takes as input the output from `genExPrior` as well as a Boolean asking whether to additionally plot the used data.

```{r}
plotExPrior(resExPrior, plotExData = TRUE)
```

As can be seen, the ex-situ prior distribution for porosity values in sandstone is strongly peaked between `0.2` and `0.3` as determined by the available data. Using this prior can therefore provide a sound foundation for geostatistical inference.
